AttributeValuesData.AttributeValue: Bigtooth Aspen is a medium-sized tree native from Nova Scotia to Ontario and Minnesota south to North Carolina, Tennessee, Illinois and Iowa. Although Bigtooth Aspen is less widespread than Quaking Aspen (with which is often grows), Bigtooth Aspen is important in reclaiming burned, logged, and eroded lands, old fields, and mine sites. Like the other trees in this family with long, flattened petioles, the leaves flutter in a slight breeze and rustle loudly in the wind. The majority of Bigtooth Aspen trees seen in a forest are actually clones that originated as root suckers rather than seedlings. Seedlings are quite rare. The name "Bigtooth" comes from the jagged leaf margins.
Pale green to gray, becoming dark gray, furrowed.
In 1 1/2 to 2 1/2" long drooping catkin, brownish, early spring.
1/4" long narrowly ovoid capsule, light green. Similar to Quaking Aspen. In 3-5" long hanging clusters (denser than in cottonwoods.) Seeds tiny, white-hairy, late spring.
Alternate, simple, on long shoots, 3-4" long, ovate to nearly circular with blunt or pointed tip. Thin, dark green, not glossy above, paler beneath. Autumn color pale to bright yellow.
Jagged leaf margins, leaves white-wooly when just unfolding

ThemeEntityData.Description: Bigtooth Aspen is a medium-sized tree native from Nova Scotia to Ontario and Minnesota south to North Carolina, Tennessee, Illinois and Iowa. Although Bigtooth Aspen is less widespread than Quaking Aspen (with which is often grows), Bigtooth Aspen is important in reclaiming burned, logged, and eroded lands, old fields, and mine sites. Like the other trees in this family with long, flattened petioles, the leaves flutter in a slight breeze and rustle loudly in the wind. The majority of Bigtooth Aspen trees seen in a forest are actually clones that originated as root suckers rather than seedlings. Seedlings are quite rare. The name "Bigtooth" comes from the jagged leaf margins.
